title: Propulsion Assignment
description: This assignment will cover the fundamental principles and theories of propulsion systems used in aerospace engineering. Students are expected to explore different types of propulsion systems, including jet, rocket, and electric propulsion, and analyze their applications and efficiency. The assignment will require a technical report detailing system performance, advantages, limitations, and a comparison of different propulsion technologies. A critical evaluation of a current or emerging propulsion technology is also required.

title: Combustion Analysis
description: The Combustion Analysis assignment will involve studying the principles of combustion as applied to aerospace propulsion systems. Students will analyze combustion processes in engines, including the chemical reactions, energy release, and efficiency. The assignment will require calculations to determine parameters such as flame temperature, combustion efficiency, and exhaust emissions. A technical report that includes analysis, calculations, and a discussion on the factors affecting combustion performance and environmental impact will be required.

title: Nozzle Design Project
description: In this project, students will design a convergent-divergent nozzle for a rocket engine. The objective is to understand the physics of gas expansion through a nozzle and to optimize nozzle geometry for maximum thrust efficiency. Students are expected to apply fluid dynamics principles, calculate flow properties, and evaluate the performance of their nozzle design. The project will require a detailed report that includes design calculations, performance analysis, and any assumptions or simplifications made during the design process.

title: Aerodynamics Quiz
description: The Aerodynamics Quiz will assess students' understanding of key concepts in aerodynamics, including fluid flow, pressure distribution, lift and drag forces, and the aerodynamic behavior of different airfoil shapes. The quiz will consist of multiple-choice questions, short-answer questions, and problem-solving exercises that require calculations. The quiz aims to evaluate students' grasp of fundamental aerodynamics principles and their ability to apply theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios.

title: Flow Analysis
description: The Flow Analysis assignment will focus on analyzing fluid flow in various engineering contexts, such as pipe flow, external flow over bodies, and boundary layer behavior. Students will use computational tools and analytical methods to determine key flow parameters, including velocity profiles, pressure drops, and turbulence characteristics. The assignment will require a report that includes flow analysis results, relevant calculations, and a discussion of the implications of the findings for engineering design and performance.

title: Heating Analysis
description: The Heating Analysis assignment will involve examining heat transfer mechanisms in aerospace systems, including conduction, convection, and radiation. Students will analyze thermal performance in different engineering scenarios, such as heat exchangers and spacecraft thermal control systems. The assignment will require a detailed report that includes heat transfer calculations, thermal analysis, and a discussion on the methods used to enhance or control heat transfer in aerospace applications.

title: Structural Design Task
description: The Structural Design Task will involve designing a structural component for an aerospace application, focusing on strength, stability, and weight optimization. Students will be required to apply concepts of material selection, stress analysis, and structural mechanics to create a design that meets specified performance criteria. The assignment will require a report that includes design calculations, material justifications, stress analysis results, and a discussion on the structural integrity and feasibility of the proposed design.

title: Orbital Calculations
description: The Orbital Calculations assignment will require students to analyze the motion of satellites and other objects in orbit. Students will apply orbital mechanics principles to determine key parameters, such as orbital velocity, altitude, period, and energy requirements for different types of orbits. The assignment will also involve solving problems related to orbital transfers, including Hohmann transfers and inclination changes. A report detailing calculations, methodologies, and implications for mission planning will be required.

title: Systems Engineering Exam
description: The Systems Engineering Exam will assess students' understanding of systems engineering concepts, including requirements analysis, system design, integration, verification, and validation. The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions, short-answer questions, and scenario-based problem-solving exercises. The goal is to evaluate students' ability to apply systems thinking and engineering principles to design and manage complex aerospace systems effectively.
